prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will observe the emission of the CS (2-1)line in and around the nucleus of M61 (~1500 pc) with a 0.45" (~35pc) spatial resolution. This requires a single pointing that fully covers the nucleus of this galaxy. We calculate our sensitivities for the CS(2-1) line making the following assumptions:
There are no single dish or interferometric observations for CS for this galaxy. Hence, the expected fluxes for the CS (2-1) line were estimated in the folowing way. We used the CO 1-0 CARMA observed flux (Momose et al. 2010). Based on the line ratio CO 1-0/CS 2-1 ~ 50 obsereved for similar source (NGC1068, Aladro et al. 2013) we estimate the CS peak flux intensity of 260 mJy/beam. We note that the CO data from CARMA only recorvered 60% of the flux of the NRO45m single dish flux. Though we expect CS to be much more compact than CO, we use the interfermetric flux to account for the missing flux affecting also CS at the high reolution requested. In the worst case of the flux being homogenously distributed over the CARMA 3.1" x 2.5" beam, we would expect a flux within the reqested 0.45" beam of 8.4 mJy. Thus we require a 0.84 mJy rms to achieve a 10 sigma mapping of the requested of CS emission.
In the proposed set up, two more lines will be observed: HCN(1-0) and SiO(2-1). These lines are a bonus on top of our primary science goals and therefore our sensitivity calculations are driven by CS.
Observations for this line require a total of 59 minutes.

We choose the lowest possible spectral resolution to allow for maximum observing time. Our line widths are expected be at least 50 km/s. We do not see the need for higher spectral resolution. Appoximately 17 elements per line will be more than necessary. We use spectral averaging of a factor of 4 to reduce the data rate.

We chose our angular reolution of 0.45" is based on the size of Giant Molecular Clouds (GMCs). These can vary from 10 - 100 pc across (Murray, 2011). At the disatnce to our target this is ~ 35 pc. This will allow us to see down to scales of at most a few GMCs, while keeping observations within a reasonable timeframe. We keep this constant across all bands in order to complete our science goals.
The chosen LAS of 2" was chosen based on CARMA data from Momose et al, 2010.

We will observe the emission of the CS (3-2)line in and around the nucleus of M61 (~1500 pc) with a 0.45" (~35pc) spatial resolution. This requires a single pointing that fully covers the nucleus of this galaxy. We calculate our sensitivities for the CS(3-2) line making the following assumptions:
We usesd the estimate of the peak flux of the CS 2-1 line (see Justification for Science Goal Band 3; based on the CS survey by Bayet et al. (2009). We note that the ratio of peak intensities between CS 3-2 to CS 2-1 varies between 1 and 2.5 (note that the variation is in fact expected - see our Figure 2). Assuming the conservative ratio of 1 we expect therefore the same peak flux as the 2-1 line.
In the proposed set up, the CH3OH(3-2) ladder will also be available. This is a bonus on top of our primary science goals and therefore our sensitivity calculations are driven by CS.
Observations for this line require a total of 53 minutes.
Our correlator set up is based on expected line widths. We use speactral averaging by a factor of 2 to reduce the data rate. See Band 3 for further justification
Our angular scale is again based on the size of GMCs and is chosen to be the same as all other bands. See Band 3 justification.

We will observe the emission of the CS (6-5)line in and around the nucleus of M61 (~1500 pc) with a 0.45" (~35pc) spatial resolution. This requires a single pointing that fully covers the nucleus of this galaxy. We calculate our sensitivities for the CS(6-5) line making the following assumptions:
We could not find any relavent CS (6-5) single dish observations of nearby galxies similar to M61. However, from the Bayet et al 2009 CS survey, we note a large range of CS (5-4)/(2-1) ratios going from 0.7 to 1.5. Assuming a conservative one of 0.8 we estimate the peak flux to be 6.7 mJy.
for this line we will accept an rms of 1 mJy and hence observations for this line require a total of 51 minutes.
Our correlator set up is based on our expected line widths. We use spectral averaging by a factor of 2 to reduce the data rate. See Band 3 for further justification.
Our angular resolution is selected based on the size of GMCs. See Band 3 for further justification.

We will observe the emission of the CS (7-6)line in and around the nucleus of M61 (~1500 pc) with a 0.45" (~35pc) spatial resolution. This requires a single pointing that fully covers the nucleus of this galaxy. We calculate our sensitivities for the CS(7-6) assuming the same numbers for the 6-5. We are aware that the peak fluxes for the two high J transitions in Band 7 are uncertain. However, we are aiming at detecting gas at different excitation conditions and our assumptions for these two lines have been using single dish observations whose average gas temperature will be lower that for some of our gas componentns.
For this line we require a total of 57 minutes.
Our correlator set up is based on our expected line widths. We use spectral averaging by a factor of 2 to reduce data rates. See Band 3 for further justification.
Our angular resolution is selected on the basis of size of GMCS. See Band 3 for further justification.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to map the emission of the dense gas tracer CS in the nearby starburst galaxy M61(NGC4303). We intend to map both low J (CS(2-1) and CS(3-2)) and high J (CS(6-5) and CS(7-6)) to trace gas ranging in densities and temperatures. This project will utilise the unique spatial resolution (0.45'') and sensitivity of ALMA to observe structure down to size of ~35pc, allowing us to resolve structures down to the scale of Giant Molecular Clouds. This builds on previous observations from the IRAM-30m telescope, which showed clear differentiation in CS emission around the central few hundred parsecs of the similar starburst galaxy NGC6946.
